This can't possibly be a set (otherwise we run into Russell's paradox), so we need to either modify our ontology (and work with "classes" instead of "sets", and call a class a "set" when it's a member of a class) or extend our ontology (to include a "class" as a third species of object). We will discuss this when the time comes, but the ontology is mildly flexible.
We [pretend to] define a [naive] Set to be a well-defined unordered collection of objects.
If x is an object and X is a set, then we write x\in X if x is an element (or member) of X. If x is not an element of X, then we write x\notin X.

We will also write X
i x as a synonym for x\in X. We also write X
ot 
i x.
This isn't really a definition, because set theory is given axiomatically. We usually give axioms to specify the behaviour of the binary infixed predicate \in .
When we define a new term in Mathematics, we should prove it is well-defined. What this proof requires depends on what we're defining.

fr:ul.fr:li: A new constant (possibly parametrized by other objects) C defined as satisfying some condition \Phi [C] requires proving (1) its existence (i.e, proving \exists x\ldotp \Phi [x]), and (2) its uniqueness (i.e., \forall x,y\ldotp \Phi [x]\land \Phi [y]\implies x=y).
A new constant C which is defined as abbreviating some complicated expression is usually well-defined, sometimes we need to prove it has the "correct type".
A new species of thing (like a vector space or a Field) should require proving the existence of at least one such gadget.
All other types of definitions (predicates, adjectives, etc.) are well-defined.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: One of the reasons why the "definition" of a set is not really a definition is because we should prove the existence of a set, but that's not possible. It's also why Mathematicians invented axiomatic set theory: presumably there are mathematical objects called "sets" which already exist, and we're trying to specify their behaviour (or some reasonable approximation) using axioms.
We have some very common sets encountered in Mathematics, so we have special notation for them:

fr:ul.fr:li: \mathbb {N}_{0}=\{0,1,2,3,…\} the set of all non-negative integers
\mathbb {N}=\{1,2,3,4,…\} the set of all positive integers
\mathbb {Z}=\{…,-3,-2,-1,0,1,2,3,…\} the set of all integers
\mathbb {Q}=\{\frac {m}{n}\mid m\in \mathbb {Z},n\in \mathbb {N} the set of all rational numbers
\mathbb {R} the set of real numbers
\mathbb {C}=\{x+\mathrm {i} y\mid x,y\in \mathbb {R}\} the set of complex numbers

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: If we have a set consisting of finitely many elements, we write it out as a comma-separated list delimited by \{…\}.
For example, the set of prime numbers less than 10 is \{2,3,5,7\}.
Let X be a set. We say X is Empty if there is no object x such that x\in X.

Let X and Y be sets. We define the predicate Set Equality (or just equality) of X and Y, denoted X=Y, to mean they have the same elements; i.e., for all objects x we have x\in X if and only if x\in Y.
When X and Y are not equal, we write X\neq Y.
(This is technically an axiom of ZFC called the "axiom of extensionality".)
We define the empty set to be the constant denoted \emptyset (or sometimes \{\}).
We need to prove this is well-defined. For constants, this means proving it exists and is unique.
Existence: Take the empty list as a set \{\}. This is clearly empty.
Uniqueness: Suppose we have X and Y both be empty sets. We want to prove X=Y. Then for any object x, we want to prove (1) if x\in X then x\in Y, and (2) if x\in Y then x\in X.
(1) Assume x\in X. But X is empty, so X cannot have any members. Then we have a contradiction. Hence we can conclude whatever we want, in particular x\in Y.
(2) The argument is the same but switching X and Y.

Let X and Y be sets. We define the predicate X\subseteq Y to mean: for any object x, if x\in X then x\in Y. In other words, all elements of X are also elements of Y. (This is very different than X is an element of Y!)
We write Y\supseteq X as a synonym for X\subseteq Y.
We also write X\nsubseteq Y as the antonym for X\subseteq Y, and Y\nsupseteq X for the antonym of Y\supseteq X.
Observe that X\subseteq X for any set X.
Let X and Y be sets. We define the predicate X\subset Y to mean X\subseteq Y and X\neq Y.
We also have the synonym Y\supset X for X\subset Y.

The choice of notation varies wildly. Some authors do not even distinguish proper subsets from "improper" subsets. Worse, some use \subset for improper subsets. We have chosen to use notation analogous to \leq and \lt .
Generically, when we want to prove Set equality like proving X=Y, we can use the Subset predicate to prove two claims: (1) X\subseteq Y, (2) Y\subseteq X.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Set builder notation
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The Working Mathematician usually "suppresses" (omits) the x\in X clause when it is understood.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Sentences in set theory
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.2

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The allowed sentences or predicates appearing in set builder notation may be described recursively.
We can describe what possible formulas appear using the following:

fr:ul.fr:li: x\in X and X=Y are the atomic formulas
"not <formula>"
"<formula> and <formula>" or just a comma-separated list of formulas, all of which are expected to hold
"<formula> or <formula>" for the disjunction of formulas (in the sense of "either <formula> or <formula> or both")
"if <formula> then <formula>" (or "<formula> implies <formula>")
"<formula> iff <formula>"
"for all …"
"for some …" (or "exists …")

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: … as well as using any predicates we've defined (like the Subset predicate).
Suppose we try defining the set R=\{S\hbox { is a set}\mid S\notin S\}. Then we obtain a contradiction if such a set exists. (The solution is to restrict what set-builder notation.)
Well, assume R exists. We will prove we obtain a contradiction. Our proof is by cases: either R\in R or R\notin R.
Case 1: Assume R\in R. Then this means R\notin R. But we have both R\in R and R\notin R which is a contradiction.
Case 2: Assume R\notin R. But this is the defining property for members of R. This implies R\in R. Again, we have both R\in R and R\notin R which is a contradiction.

fr:title.text: There is no set of all sets

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: There is no set of all sets

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: An immediate consequence of Russell's paradox is that there is no set of all sets. If there were a set V of all sets, then V\in V which leads to problems.
We will often informally refer to a (Proper) Class as an unordered collection which is "too big" to be a set.
For example, the von Neumann universe \mathbf {V} is the proper class of all sets.
In practice, we seldom need to work with proper classes directly. The Working Mathematician needs only sets (until we get to Category Theory, but we'll revisit this as needed).
The Axiom of limitation of size asserts a collection C is a proper class if and only if there exists a surjective function from C to the von Neumann universe \mathbf {V}.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: We're playing "fast and loose" with things here, but for a discussion of axiomatic set theory based on classes (using the NBG axioms), see Taras Banakh's Classical Set Theory: Theory of Sets and Classes.

fr:title.text: Union of a family of sets

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Union of a family of sets
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let F be a family of sets (i.e., set whose elements are sets). We define the Union of F to be the set \bigcup F such that for all objects x we have x\in \bigcup F iff there is some set X\in F such that x\in X.
This defines a new constant and we should set about to proving it is well-defined, but proving its existence is impossible because it is just stipulated to exist ("axiom of union").

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Union of two sets
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X and Y be sets. We define the Union of X and Y to be the set X\cup Y such that for all objects x we have x\in X\cup Y iff either x\in X or x\in Y.
We see that this is commutative X\cup Y=Y\cup X and idempotent X\cup X=X.
Existence: take X\cup Y=\bigcup \{X,Y\}. We need to prove x\in X\cup Y\implies x\in \bigcup \{X,Y\} and x\in \bigcup \{X,Y\}\implies x\in X\cup Y, but these follow immediately.

Uniqueness: Suppose A is such that for all x we have x\in A iff x\in X or x\in Y, and B is such that for all x we have x\in B iff x\in X or x\in Y. We will prove for all x we have x\in A iff x\in B: let x be an arbitrary object. Then x\in A\iff x\in A\hbox { or }x\in A\iff x\in B which implies x\in A\iff x\in B. Hence A=B by Set equality.

fr:title.text: Basic properties of union of two sets

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Basic properties of union of two sets
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let A, B, C be arbitrary sets. Then the following all hold:

fr:ol.fr:li: Associativity: A\cup (B\cup C)=(A\cup B)\cup C
A\subseteq B iff A\cup B=B

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Intersection of two sets
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X and Y be sets. We define their Intersection to be the set denoted X\cap Y such that: for all objects x we have x\in X\cap Y iff x\in X and x\in Y.
We see this is commutative X\cap Y=Y\cap X and idempotent X\cap X=X.
Existence: We see this exists using set-builder notation \{x\in X\mid x\in Y\}.
Uniqueness: let A and B be two possible candidates for the definition. We see x\in A\iff x\in X\hbox { and }x\in Y\iff x\in B, which implies A=B by Set equality.

fr:title.text: Basic properties of intersection of two sets

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Basic properties of intersection of two sets
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let A, B, C be any three sets. Then the following all hold:

fr:ol.fr:li: A\subseteq B iff A\cap B=A

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Intersection of family of sets
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.4

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let F be a family of sets (i.e., a set whose members are all sets). We define the Intersection of F to be the set \bigcap F such that for all objects x we have x\in \bigcap F iff for each set Y\in F we have x\in Y.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Relative complement of a set
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.5

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X and Y be sets. We define the Relative complement of X with respect to Y to be the set Y\setminus X such that for all objects x we have x\in Y\setminus X iff x\in Y and x\notin X.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Complement of a subset
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.5

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X be a subset of Y. We define the Complement of X to be the subset X^{\complement } of Y equal to Y\setminus X.
Some texts use \complement X or X' for the complement of X.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Powerset
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.5

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X be a set. We define the Powerset of X to be the set \mathcal {P}(X) such that for any set Z we have Z\in \mathcal {P}(X) iff Z\subseteq X. That is to say, the powerset of X is the set of all subsets of X.

For finite sets (especially small sets we can write out by hand), we can see this is a sensible thing to define. But for infinite sets, some Mathematicians historically were nervous about this being well-defined. The important thing is that we assert (either axiomatically or dogmatically) this is indeed a set.
(In ZFC, this is given as an axiom.)
Let x and y be objects. Let a and b be objects. We expect the ordered pair (x,y) to be such that: (x,y)=(a,b) if and only if x=a and y=b.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Ordered pairs
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.6

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let x and y be objects. We define the Ordered Pair to be the object (x,y) = \{\{x\},\{x,y\}\}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Ordered pairs implement their specification
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.6

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let a, b, c, d be objects. If (a,b)=(c,d), then a=c and b=d.
We boild this proof down to two cases: either c=d or not. We assume (a,b)=(c,d).
Case 1: c=d. Then (c,d)=(c,c)=\{\{c,c\},\{c\}\}=\{\{c\}\} and (a,b)=\{\{a,b\},\{a\}\}=\{\{c\}\} requires \{a,b\}=\{c\} which implies a=b=c. Hence a=b=c=d which implies a=c and b=d as desired.
Case 2: c\neq d. Then \{a\}\neq \{c,d\}, so \{a\}=\{c\}, which means a=c. Then we see (a,b)=(c,b)=(c,d) which implies \{c,b\}=\{c,d\} which means b=d. Hence a=c and b=d.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Cartesian product of two sets
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.6

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X and Y be sets. We define their Cartesian product to be the set X\times Y such that for all objects z, we have z\in X\times Y if and only if there exists objects x and y such that x\in X and y\in Y and z=(x,y).
Let X, Y, Z be sets. Then the following all hold:

fr:ol.fr:li: X\times Y=\emptyset iff X=\emptyset or Y=\emptyset
If X\times Y=Y\times X, then X=Y

fr:title.text: Relations and functions in naive set theory

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Relations and functions in naive set theory
Relation
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.7

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We can define a Relation broadly is a set R such that for all objects r\in R there exists objects x and y such that r=(x,y). In other words, a relation is a set which consists of ordered pairs.
When X and Y are sets, a Relation of X and Y is a subset R\subseteq X\times Y.
We will speak of a "Relation of X" when referring to a subset R\subseteq X\times X.

If R is a relation and (x,y)\in R, then we will frequently abuse notation and write x\;R\;y. Usually instead of R, for particular relations we use \sim , \approx , \cong , \equiv , \lt , or other notation which is more aesthetically pleasing.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Domain of a relation
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.7

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a relation. We define the Domain of R to be the set \mathop {\textrm {dom}}\nolimits (R)=\{x\mid \exists y\ldotp (x,y)\in R\}.
When R is a relation of X and Y, we see \mathop {\textrm {dom}}\nolimits (R)\subseteq X.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Range of a relation
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.7

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a relation. We define the Range of R to be the set \mathop {\textrm {ran}}\nolimits (R)=\{y\mid \exists x\ldotp (x,y)\in R\}.
When R is a relation of X and Y, we see \mathop {\textrm {ran}}\nolimits (R)\subseteq Y.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Field of a relation
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.7

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a relation. We define the Field of R is just \mathop {\textrm {dom}}\nolimits (R)\cup \mathop {\textrm {ran}}\nolimits (R).
Observe when R is a relation of X and Y, the field F of R is a subset F\subseteq X\cup Y.
Let R be a relation. We define the Inverse of R to be the relation R^{-1}=\{(y,x)\mid (x,y)\in R\}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Reflexive relation
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.7

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a relation, let F be its field. We say R is Reflexive if for each x\in F we have (x,x)\in R.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Symmetric relation
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.7

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a relation, let F be its field. We say R is Symmetric if for all x\in F and y\in F, if (x,y)\in R, then (y,x)\in R.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Transitive relation
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.7

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let R be a relation, let F be its field. We say R is Transitive if for all x\in F, y\in F, and z\in F, if (x,y)\in R and (y,z)\in R, then (x,z)\in R.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Equivalence relation
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.7

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X be a set. We define an Equivalence Relation of X to be a reflexive symmetric transitive relation of X.
For example, R=\{(x,x)\mid x\in X\} is always an equivalence relation of X which describes equality of elements of X.
More generally, an equivalence relation is a generalization of equality. Consequently, it is common to use notation like \sim , \approx , \equiv , \cong for equivalence relations.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Equivalence class
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.7

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X be a set, let x\in X, and let R be an equivalence relation of X. We define the Equivalence Class of x with respect to R is the set [x]_{R}=\{y\in X\mid (x,y)\in R\} consisting of all elements equivalent to x under R.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Composing relations
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.7

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let P and R be relations. We define their Composition to be the relation denoted PR or R\circ P such that for all objects x and z we have (x,z)\in PR iff there exists an object y such that (x,y)\in P and (y,z)\in R.
The PR notation means xPRz iff there exists a y such that xPyRz.
The R\circ P notation is useful for working with functions.
Let R_{1}, R_{2}, R_{3} be relations. Then (R_{1}\circ R_{2})\circ R_{3}=R_{1}\circ (R_{2}\circ R_{3}).

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Function
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.8

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
Let X and Y be sets. We define a Function from X to Y to be a relation of X and Y denoted f\colon X\to Y such that:
Total: \mathop {\textrm {dom}}\nolimits (f)=X, and
Function-like: for all objects x, y, z such that (x,y)\in f and (x,z)\in f, we have y=z. Instead of (x,y)\in f, we write f(x)=y.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Set of all functions
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.8

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X and Y be sets. We denote the Set of all functions from X to Y as either Y^{X} or \hom (X,Y).
We see this really is a set, since a function is a subset of X\times Y, so the set of all functions is a subset of \mathcal {P}(X\times Y).

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Inclusion
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.8

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X be a subset of Y. Then the Inclusion of X into Y is the function i\colon X\to Y defined by i(x)=x for all x\in X.
Let X be a set. We define the Identity Function of X to be the function \mathop {\textrm {id}}\nolimits _{X}\colon X\to X such that for all x\in X, \mathop {\textrm {id}}\nolimits _{X}(x)=x.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Restriction of a function
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.8

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let g\colon Y\to Z be a function, let X\subseteq Y. We define the Restriction of g to X to be the function g|_{X}\colon X\to Z such that for all x\in X, g|_{X}(x)=g(x).

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Projection of Cartesian product
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.8

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X and Y be sets. We define the Projection Functions \pi _{1}\colon X\times Y\to X and \pi _{2}\colon X\times Y\to Y by \pi _{1}(x,y)=x and \pi _{2}(x,y)=y for all x\in X and y\in Y.
Let f\colon X\to Y and g\colon Y\to Z be functions. Then the Composition of f followed by g is the function g\circ f\colon X\to Z defined by (g\circ f)(x)=g(f(x)) for all x\in X.
Observe this is just the Composing relations.
Let f\colon W\to X, g\colon X\to Y, h\colon Y\to Z be functions. Then h\circ (g\circ f)=(h\circ g)\circ f.
This follows from composing relations is associative.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Preimage of a function
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.10

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let f\colon X\to Y be a function, let B\subseteq Y. We define the Preimage of B under f to be the set f^{-1}(A)=\{x\in X\mid f(x)\in B\}.
This is sometimes denoted f^{*}(B) to avoid confusing the preimage with the inverse function of f. This allows us to interpret f^{*}\colon \mathcal {P}(Y)\to \mathcal {P}(X) without ambiguity.
Let X and Y be sets, let f\colon X\to Y be a function. We define the Image (or Range) of f to be the subset \mathop {\textrm {ran}}\nolimits (f)=f(X)=\{f(x)\in Y\mid x\in X\}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Direct image of a function
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.10

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let f\colon X\to Y be a function. Let A\subseteq X. We define the Direct Image of A under f to be the set f(A)=\{f(x)\in Y\mid x\in A\}.
We sometimes use the notation f_{*}(A) for the direct image of A under f, so we can describe a function f_{*}\colon \mathcal {P}(X)\to \mathcal {P}(Y).

fr:title.text: Properties of image and preimage of a function

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Properties of image and preimage of a function
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Paul R. Halmos Naive Set Theory Ch.10

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let f\colon X\to Y be a function, let A\subseteq X, and B\subseteq Y. Then the following all hold:

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Preimages preserve everything
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Nicolas Bourbaki Theory of Sets R §2.10

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let f\colon X\to Y be a function, let L\subseteq Y and R\subseteq Y be subsets. Then the following all hold:

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Direct image preserves only union
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Nicolas Bourbaki Theory of Sets R§2.5

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let f\colon X\to Y be a function, let L\subseteq X and R\subseteq X be subsets. Then the following all hold:
Let f\colon X\to Y be a function. We say f is Surjective (or that it's a surjection) if for each y\in Y there is at least one x\in X such that f(x)=y.
In other words, the image of f is the codomain of f. Or more vividly, f "covers" all of Y.
Let f\colon X\to Y be an Surjective function. Then there exists a function g\colon Y\to X such that f\circ g=\mathop {\textrm {id}}\nolimits _{Y}.
We call such a g a Right Inverse of f.
Let f\colon X\to Y be a function. We say f is injective (or that it's a injection) if for all x_{1},x_{2}\in X such that f(x_{1})=f(x_{2}) we have x_{1}=x_{2}.
Equivalently, if f(x_{1})\neq f(x_{2}), then x_{1}\neq x_{2}.
So no two distinct elements of X are mapped to the same element under f.

fr:title.text: Injective functions have a left inverse function

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Injective functions have a left inverse function

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let f\colon X\to Y be an Injective function. Then there exists a function g\colon Y\to X such that g\circ f=\mathop {\textrm {id}}\nolimits _{X}.
We call such a g a Left Inverse of f.
We say a function f\colon X\to Y is Bijective (or say f is a bijection) if f is both injective and surjective.
This means for each y\in Y, there exists a unique x\in X such that f(x)=y.

Let f\colon X\to Y be a function. We call a function g\colon Y\to X the Inverse of f if f\circ g=\mathop {\textrm {id}}\nolimits _{Y} and g\circ f=\mathop {\textrm {id}}\nolimits _{X}. When such a g exists, we denote it by f^{-1}.

Let f\colon X\to Y be an Bijective function. Then there exists a function g\colon Y\to X such that f\circ g=\mathop {\textrm {id}}\nolimits _{Y} and g\circ f=\mathop {\textrm {id}}\nolimits _{X}. Moreover this function g is unique.
We call such a g the Inverse of f, and we usually denote it by f^{-1}=g.
We see that if (x,y)\in f, then (y,x)\in g.
We call a set A Finite if there exists a non-negative integer n\in \mathbb {N}_{0} such that \{k\in \mathbb {N}\mid k\leq n\} is bijective with A.
Otherwise, we call A Infinite.
We call a set A Countable if there is an injective map A\to \mathbb {N}.
Otherwise we call A Uncountable.
When A is infinite, A is countable iff there is a bijection A\to \mathbb {N} (or a bijection \mathbb {N}\to A). In this case, we will call A Countably Infinite (or Denumerable).

Caution: some authors say A is countable if there is an bijective function A\to \mathbb {N}. This seems to be the case among analysts, but I don't think I could live with myself if I were to follow their example.

fr:title.text: A set bijective with a countably infinite set is countably infinite

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A set bijective with a countably infinite set is countably infinite

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let A be a set, let B be a countably infinite set. Then A is countably infinite iff there is a bijection f\colon A\to B.
Let g\colon B\to \mathbb {N} be an injective function (since B is countable). If f\colon A\to B is bijective, then g\circ f is injective, hence A is countable.
If A is countably infinite, then there is a bijection g\colon A\to \mathbb {N}. We have h\colon B\to \mathbb {N} be bijective (since B is countable). Then h^{-1}\circ g\colon A\to B is bijective.
Let A be a set. A Sequence of A is a function f\colon \mathbb {N}\to A, where we usually write f_{n} instead of f(n).
Let A be a countably infinite set. We Enumerate the elements of A by producing an bijection \mathbb {N}\to A as a sequence.
Conversely, if there is a sequence of A which is bijective, then we call that sequence an Enumeration of A.

fr:title.text: Every infinite subset of a countably infinite set is countable

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Every infinite subset of a countably infinite set is countable

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let A be a countably infinite set, let E\subseteq A be infinite. Then E is countable.
Since A is countably infinite, we can enumerate its elements as a sequence x_{n}.
We can construct a sequence (n_{k}) of positive integers such that x_{n_{k}}\in E.
Then we have the sequence f(k)=x_{n_{k}} which enumerates the elements of E.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: \mathbb {Q} is countable
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Principles of Mathematical Analysis, Corollary to Theorem 2.13

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The set of rational numbers is countably infinite.

fr:title.text: Set of all sequences of 0,1 is uncountable

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Set of all sequences of \{0,1\} is uncountable

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let A be the set of all sequences of \{0,1\}. Then the set A is uncountable.
This means every countably infinite subset of A is a proper subset. This means A must be uncountable since otherwise it would be a proper subset of itself, which is impossible.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This implies \mathbb {R} is uncountable since A contains the binary expansion of all real numbers between 0 and 1.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X be a set. We say X is Transitive if for all sets x\in X we have x\subseteq X. In other words, if x\in X and y\in X, then y\in X. So \in forms a transitive relation on X.
Let X be a set. We say X is Connected if for all sets x\in X and y\in X, if x\notin y and x\neq y, then y\in x.
We say a set X is an Ordinal if X is Transitive set and also Connected set.
Let X be a set. We define the Successor of X to be the set \mathop {\textrm {S}}\nolimits (X):=X\cup \{X\}.

fr:title.text: Successor of ordinal is an ordinal

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Successor of ordinal is an ordinal

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X be an Ordinal number. Then \mathop {\textrm {S}}\nolimits (X) is an Ordinal number, too.

fr:title.text: Union of ordinal is an ordinal

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Union of ordinal is an ordinal

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X be an Ordinal number. Then \bigcup X is an Ordinal number, too.
Let A be a set. We say A is a Limit Ordinal if A=\bigcup A.
Note: this means that \emptyset is a limit ordinal.
Let A be an ordinal number. Then the following are equivalent:

fr:ol.fr:li: A is a Limit ordinal
for each ordinal C\in A we have \mathop {\textrm {S}}\nolimits (C)\in A
there is no ordinal B such that A=\mathop {\textrm {S}}\nolimits (B)

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
We define \omega to be the ordinal such that:
contains zero: \emptyset \in \omega , and
limit: \omega is a Limit ordinal
smallest such ordinal: for any other ordinal A such that \emptyset \in A and A is a Limit ordinal, we have \omega \subseteq A.
This is the set theoretic construction of the natural numbers, where 0 is identified as \emptyset , and for any n\in \omega we identify n+1 with \mathop {\textrm {S}}\nolimits (n).

fr:title.text: There is no set of all ordinals

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: There is no set of all ordinals

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: There is no set X such that for all ordinals A we have A\in X. In other words, there is no set of all ordinal numbers.

Assume for contradiction that X is a set such that for all ordinals A, we have A\in X. Then X is Transitive set and Connected set, which implies X is an Ordinal number. Then X\in X, which is impossible.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: "The collection of all ordinal numbers" is another example of a proper class.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let A be an Ordinal number. We say A is a Cardinal number if for every ordinal B such that A is bijective to B we have A\subseteq B.
Let X be a set. We define the Cardinality of X to be the Cardinal number |X| such that X is equipotent with |X|.
So the cardinality of X is the smallest Ordinal number bijective with X.
Usually, we only care if |X| is finite or not.
This is the forest of my notes on Mathematics. It's an attempt to describe the "mental landscape" of Mathematics, at least how I view it (based on how I learned it).

fr:title.text: Naive handling of material followed by rigorous presentation

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Naive handling of material followed by rigorous presentation

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: There is a "naive" introduction to some of the material: in Elementary linear algebra, for example, we just assume the real numbers exist and familiarity with calculating with them (at least to the level expected of a calculus student). But it isn't until Classical Analysis where constructing real numbers is really examined.

Arguably this "circular" treatment of material is a pedagogical virtue when actually "executed" in practice: the student will study Elementary linear algebra one quarter, then intermediate linear algebra the next quarter, then Classical Analysis the following quarter. This spaces out the material and the review, which strengthens mental connections.

For better or worse, this forest of notes lacks that quality. After all, you can sit down and just "cram" the notes, possibly over the course of several days. So for you, the reader, you will not have the advantage of spaced learning.
Also I am being a bit sparse when giving proofs in the earlier parts of the forest. So Elementary linear algebra lacks proofs for every theorem, but they could be supplied if desired.

The choice to order material partially reflects how I learned it (Elementary linear algebra, followed by intermediate linear algebra, then Classical Analysis, and so on) and partially how I mentally think of the material: linear algebra is the "central" subject in Mathematics, and everything "branches off" from it.
This means we successively review linear algebra in greater generality.

Moreover, I have decided to "cluster" trees into "subforests" reflecting the course materials. This means each "identifier" for a tree is prefixed by some "slug" for the "subforest". Sometimes (like with field or sl) a mathematical object or gadget is used as the slug. Othertimes (like with ela or ca) the course name is used.
Let S be a set. An Order on S is a Relation denoted < such that:

fr:ol.fr:li: Trichotomy: If x\in S and y\in S, then exactly one of the following is true: x<y or x=y or y<x;
Transitivity: If x,y,z\in S, if x<y and y<z, then x<z.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We will write y>x as a synonym for x<y.
We will also write x\leq y as a synonym for "x<y or x=y".
An Ordered Set consists of a set S equipped with an Order.
Let S be an Ordered Set, and let E\subseteq S. If there exists a \beta \in S such that x\leq \beta for every x\in E, then we say E is Bounded Above and call \beta an Upper Bound of E.
Lower bounds are defined similarly: a Lower Bound \alpha \in S such that \alpha \leq x for every x\in E, and we say E is Bounded Below.
Let S be an Ordered Set, let E\subseteq S, and suppose E is bounded above. Suppose there exists an \alpha \in S such that:

fr:ol.fr:li: \alpha is an upper bound of E; and
If \gamma <\alpha , then \gamma is not an upper bound of E.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Then we call \alpha the Least Upper Bound of E, or the Supremum of E, and we denote this by \alpha =\sup (E).
Let S be an Ordered Set, let E\subseteq S, and suppose E is bounded below. Suppose there exists an \alpha \in S such that:

fr:ol.fr:li: \alpha is an lower bound of E; and
If \alpha <\gamma , then \gamma is not a lower bound of E.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Then we call \alpha the Greatest Lower Bound of E, or the Infinimum of E, and we denote this by \alpha =\inf (E).
An Ordered Set S is said to have the Least-Upper-Bound Property if the following is true:
For any subset E\subseteq S, if E is non empty and E is bounded above, then \sup (E) exists in S.

fr:title.text: Subsets of a LUB-set which are bounded below have a supremum

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Subsets of a LUB-set which are bounded below have a supremum

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Suppose S is an Ordered Set with the Least-Upper-Bound Property, let B\subseteq S be non-empty and suppose B is bounded below. Let L be the set of all lower bounds of B. Then \alpha =\sup (L) exists in S and \alpha =\inf (B).
A Field is traditionally defined as a set F with two binary operators, addition (denoted +) and multiplication (denoted \cdot ), satisfying the field axioms:

fr:ol.fr:li: Associativity of addition: for all x,y,z\in F, (x+y)+z=x+(y+z)
Commutativity of addition: for all x,y\in F, x+y=y+x
Additive identity: there exists a 0\in F such that for all x\in F we have 0+x=x and x+0=x
Additive inverses: for each x\in F there is a unique y\in F such that x+y=0 and y+x=0; in this case, we usually denote y as (-x)
Associativity of multiplication: for all x,y,z\in F, (x\cdot y)\cdot z=x\cdot (y\cdot z)
Commutativity of multiplication: for all x,y\in F, x\cdot y=y\cdot x
Multiplicative identity: there exists a 1\in F such that for all x\in F we have 1\cdot x=x and x\cdot 1=x
Multiplicative inverses: for each x\in F which is nonzero x\neq 0 there is a unique y\in F such that x\cdot y=1 and y\cdot x=1; usually we denote y as x^{-1}
Distributivity of multiplication over addition: for all x,y,z\in F, we have x\cdot (y+z)=(x\cdot y)+(x\cdot z) and (x+y)\cdot z=(x\cdot z)+(x\cdot y)

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Note that some of these are redundant.
Also note: fields are usually written in blackboard bold, and the generic field is either \mathbb {F} or \Bbbk (since the German word for field is "Körper").
There exists an ordered field R which has the Least-Upper-Bound Property. Moreover, R contains the rational numbers \mathbb {Q} as a subfield.
Step 1: Define R as the set of all Dedekind cuts
Step 2: Ordering the Dedekind cuts.
Step 3: The set of Dedekind cuts has the least-upper bound property.
Step 4: Construct addition operator on the set of Dedekind cuts.
Step 5: Addition of Dedekind cuts satisfies the relevant ordered field axioms.
Step 6: Construct multiplication operator on subset of positive Dedekind cuts.
Step 7: Finish constructing mutliplication of Dedekind cuts, and it forms an ordered field.
Step 8: Identify a subset of Dedekind cuts with the rational numbers.
Step 9: The "rational" Dedekind cuts are isomorphic to the field of rational numbers.

Suppose we have two ordered fields R_{1} and R_{2} which both have the Least-Upper-Bound Property and each contain the rational numbers \mathbb {Q} as a subfield. Then there exists an order-preserving field isomorphism f\colon R_{1}\to R_{2}, i.e., R_{1} is isomorphic to R_{2}.
Since the ordered field R with the LUB property and containing \mathbb {Q} is essentially unique, we refer to it as the Real Numbers and write it as \mathbb {R}.
Just a sketch of the proof.

Step 1: the fields R_{1} and R_{2} are both character zero, i.e., there is no n\in \mathbb {N} such that 1_{R} + \cdots + 1_{R}=0 (the sum of n copies of 1_{R} vanishes). This is never true for either R_{1} or R_{2}.
Step 2: \mathbb {Q} is order-dense in R_{i}.
Step 3: Let f_{0}\colon \mathbb {Q}\cap R_{1}\to R_{2} be a function taking \mathbb {Q} to \mathbb {Q} in the sense that if q\in R_{1}\cap \mathbb {Q}, then f_{0}(q)=q.
We extend this f_{0} to f\colon R_{1}\to R_{2} by f(r)=\sup \{f(q)\mid q<r\} for all r\in R_{1}. Then by the order-density of \mathbb {Q}, this f is an order isomorphism.
Step 4: The f we just constructed is a field isomorphism.
Let x\in \mathbb {R}, y\in \mathbb {R}, and x>0. Then there exists a positive integer n such that nx>y.
Let x\in \mathbb {R} and y\in \mathbb {R}. If x<y, then there exists a p\in \mathbb {Q} such that x<p<y.

fr:title.text: Existence of rational roots of positive real numbers

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Existence of rational roots of positive real numbers

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let x>0 be real and n>0 be an integer. Then there exists exactly one real number y\in \mathbb {R} such that y^{n}=x.
Since this y is unique, we write it as y=x^{1/n} or y=\sqrt [n]{x} and call it the n-th root of x.
Let a>0 and b>0 be real numbers. Let n be a positive integer. Then (ab)^{1/n}=a^{1/n}b^{1/n}

The idea is to build an intuition of topology as a generalization of metric spaces. This is the pedagogically correct way to learn the material, even if it is not the easiest way to formalize it in a proof assistant.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Norm
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Linear algebra as an introduction to abstract mathematics Definition 9.1.3

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
Let V be a vector space over \mathbb {F} (usually a subfield of \mathbb {C}, but if we can give \mathbb {F} a sensible "absolute value" operation, then that works fine). A Norm on V is a function \left \lVert - \right \rVert \colon V\to \mathbb {R} such that
Positive definiteness: \left \lVert v \right \rVert =0 iff v=\vec {0}
Positive homogeneity: \left \lVert av \right \rVert =|a|\left \lVert v \right \rVert for all a\in \mathbb {F} and v\in V
Triangle inequality: \left \lVert v+w \right \rVert \leq \left \lVert v \right \rVert +\left \lVert w \right \rVert for all v,w\in V
Observe these properties imply \left \lVert v \right \rVert \geq 0 for all v\in V.
Let X be a set. We define a Metric on X to be a function d\colon X\times X\to \mathbb {R} such that:

fr:ol.fr:li: For any x\in X, we have d(x,x)=0;
Positivity: For any x,y\in X, d(x,y)\geq 0 and moreover d(x,y)=0 iff x=y.
Symmetry: For any x,y\in X, we have d(x,y)=d(y,x).
Triangle inequality: For any x,y,z\in X, we have d(x,y)+d(y,z)\geq d(x,z).

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We define a Metric Space to consist of a set X equipped with a Metric.
Let (X,d) be a Metric Space, let x\in X and r>0 be a positive real number. Then we define the Open Ball centered at x of radius r to be the set:

Let (X,d) be a Metric Space, let E\subseteq X. We say E is Open (or that E is an Open Subset of X) if for all x\in E, there exists an r>0, such that the Open Ball centered at x of radius r is contained in it: B_{r}(x)\subseteq E.

fr:title.text: Every open ball is an open set

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Every open ball is an open set

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let B_{r}(x) be an Open Ball in the Metric Space (X,d) where r>0 and x\in X. Then B_{r}(x) is an Open Set.

Suffices to show (by definition of open sets) that if x'\in B_{r}(x) and r'=r-d(x,x'), then B_{r'}(x')\subseteq B_{r}(x). Let y\in B_{r'}(x'), then d(y,x')<r'. Then the triangle inequality gives us d(x,y)\leq d(x,x')+d(x',y)<d(x,x')+r'=r. So y\in B_{r}(x). Since y\in B_{r'}(x') was arbitrary, this then implies B_{r'}(x')\subseteq B_{r}(x).
Let (X,d) be a Metric Space, let x\in X. We define a Neighborhood of x to be an open subset N_{x} of X such that it contains x\in N_{x}.

Let (X,d) be a Metric Space, let E\subseteq X be a subset, let x\in X. We say x is a Limit Point of E if every neighborhood N_{x} of x intersects N_{x}\cap E\ni y\neq x (the neighborhood intersects E in a distinct point).
Let (X,d) be a Metric Space, let E\subseteq X. We say E is a Closed Subset of X if it contains all its limit points.
The preceding definitions and notions generalize easily from a Metric Space (X,d) to a set with a well-defined notion of an "open set" (i.e., a topological space).

fr:title.text: A set may be neither open nor closed

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A set may be neither open nor closed

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (\mathbb {R},|\cdot |) be the real numbers equipped with the absolute value Norm as a Metric: d(x,y):=|x-y|. This is a Metric Space.
Let E=\{1/n\mid n\in \mathbb {N}\}. We see that E has one Limit Point at 0, but no x\in E is a limit point. Then E is not a Closed Subset of \mathbb {R} because 0\notin E.
But E is not an Open Set either. Look at B_{r}(1/2)=(\frac {1}{2}-r,\frac {1}{2}+r) which is not contained in E for any r>0.

fr:title.text: Finite subsets of metric spaces are closed

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Finite subsets of metric spaces are closed

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Any finite subset of a metric space (X,d) is a Closed Subset of X.

Let E=\{x_{1},…,x_{n}\}. We will show X\setminus E is an Open Set. So for any x\in X\setminus E, we find r>0 and r<\max \{d(x,x_{i})\mid x_{i}\in E\}. So B_{r}(x)\subseteq E^{\complement }=X\setminus E. This means E^{\complement } is open. Hence E is closed.

fr:title.text: Rationals are neither open nor closed in reals

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Rationals are neither open nor closed in reals

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The subset \mathbb {Q} of (\mathbb {R},|\cdot |) is neither a Closed Subset of \mathbb {R}, nor is it an Open Set.

fr:title.text: A set is open iff its complement is closed

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A set is open iff its complement is closed

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (X,d) be a Metric Space. Let E\subseteq X be a subset. Then E is open if and only if X\setminus E is closed.

(\Longrightarrow ) Assume E is open in X. Let x be a Limit Point of X\setminus E. Assume for contradiction x\in E. Since E is open, there is a Neighborhood of x contained in E and thus disjoint from X\setminus E. This implies x is not a Limit Point, which is a contradiction. Then x\notin E, which means x\in X\setminus E and therefore X\setminus E is closed.

(\Longleftarrow ) Assume X\setminus E is closed. For any x\in E, x is not a Limit Point of X\setminus E. Then there exists a Neighborhood N_{x} of x which does not intersect X\setminus E, so N_{x} is contained in E. Therefore E is open.

fr:title.text: Properties of open and closed subsets of metric spaces

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Properties of open and closed subsets of metric spaces

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (X,d) be a Metric Space. Then the following all hold:

fr:ol.fr:li: X is an open and closed subset of (X,d)
\emptyset is an open and closed subset of (X,d)
The union of an arbitrary collection of open subsets of (X,d) is an open subset
The intersection of finitely many open subsets of (X,d) is open
The union of finitely many closed subsets of (X,d) is closed
The intersection of an arbitrary family of closed subsets of (X,d) is closed

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (X,d) be a Metric Space. Let E\subseteq X. Then the Closure of E (denoted \overline {E}) is the union of E with its limit points.

fr:title.text: Closure of a set is the smallest closed set

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Closure of a set is the smallest closed set

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (X,d) be a Metric Space. Let E\subseteq X. Then \overline {E} is a closed subset of X. Moreover, it is the smallest closed subset of X containing E, in the sense: if F\subseteq X is closed and E\subseteq F, then \overline {E}\subseteq F.
Claim 1: \overline {E} is closed. We will prove \overline {E} contains all its limit points (and therefore \overline {E} is closed).

Let x be a Limit Point of \overline {E}. If x\in E, then by definition of Closure of a subset, x\in \overline {E}. But if x\notin E, then let N_{x} be a Neighborhood of x. There is a point x'\in \overline {E}\cap N_{x} such that x'\neq x. The by definition of \overline {E}, either x'\in E or x' is a Limit Point of E. (In the latter case, we're done.)

If x' is a limit point of E, since N_{x} is also a neighborhood of x', there is a point x''\in E\cap N_{x} with x''\neq x'. Therefore every neighborhood of x intersects E nontrivially and hence x\in \overline {E}. So the set \overline {E} is closed.
Claim 2: If A\subseteq B, then \overline {A}\subseteq \overline {B}. So if F is closed and contains E, then \overline {E}\subseteq \overline {F}=F.
Let (X,d) be a Metric Space. Let E\subseteq X. We say E is Dense in X if every point of X is either a Limit Point of E or belongs to E.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: In other words, E is dense in X if and only if \overline {E}=X.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (Y,d_{Y}) be a subspace of the Metric Space (X,d). Let E\subseteq Y. Then E is an Open Set of Y if and only if there exists an open set O\subseteq X such that E=Y\cap O.

(\Longrightarrow ) Assume E is open in Y. For each x\in E, there is a radius r_{x}>0 such that the Open Ball B_{r_{x}}(x)=\{y\in Y\mid d(x,y)<r_{x}\}\subseteq E. Let V_{x} be the set of all y\in X such that d(x,y)<r_{x} (i.e., V_{x} is the r_{x}-neighborhood of x in X). Define O=\bigcup _{x\in E}V_{x}. Then O is an open subset of X by the Properties of open and closed subsets of metric spaces.
Since for each x\in E, we see x\in V_{x} and E\subseteq Y\cap O.
By our choice of V_{x}, we have V_{x}\cap Y=B_{x}\subseteq E for each x\in X. So O\cap Y\subseteq E. Thus E=Y\cap O.
(\Longleftarrow ) If O is open in X and E=Y\cap O, then every point x\in E\subseteq O has an open neighborhood N_{x}\subseteq O. Then N_{x}\cap Y\subseteq E, so E is open relative to Y.

fr:title.text: Convergent sequence in a metric space

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Convergent sequence in a metric space

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (X,d) be a Metric Space. Let (x_{n}) be a sequence in X. We say (x_{n}) Converges to x\in X if for each \varepsilon >0 there is a corresponding N\in \mathbb {N} such that for all n\geq N, d(x,x_{n})<\varepsilon .
We call x the Limit of the sequence, and write x_{n}\to x or x=\lim _{n\to \infty }x_{n}.

Let (X_{1},d_{1}) and (X_{2},d_{2}) be two metric spaces. We define their (Cartesian) Product to be the metric space (X,d) = (X_{1}\times X_{2},d) with the Metric defined by d((x_{1},x_{2}),(y_{1},y_{2}))=d_{1}(x_{1},y_{1})d_{2}(x_{2},y_{2}) for all x_{1},x_{2}\in X_{1} and y_{1},y_{2}\in X_{2}. Furthermore (X,d) is a Metric Space.

fr:title.text: Subset is closed iff all convergent sequences on the subset have limits there

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Subset is closed iff all convergent sequences on the subset have limits there

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (X,d) be a Metric Space. Let E be a subset of X. Then E is closed if and only if whenever a sequence in E converges to a limit x\in X, the limit x belongs to E (i.e., x\in E).
Observe it suffices to prove a point x\in X\setminus E is a Limit Point if and only if x is the limit of a sequence of E.

(\Longrightarrow ) For each n>0, B_{1/n}(x)\cap E\neq \emptyset , so we may choose a point x_{n}\in B_{1/n}(x)\cap E. Then (x_{n}) is a sequence in E and it converges to x: for each \varepsilon >0, there is an N\in \mathbb {N} such that 1/N<\varepsilon . Then, for all n\geq N, d(x,x_{n})<1/n\leq 1/N<\varepsilon .
(\Longleftarrow ) If a sequence in E converges to x, then every ball centered at x contains infinitely many terms of the sequence and therefore contains points in E. So x is a Limit Point of E.

Let (X,d) be a Metric Space. Let (x_{n}) be a sequence in X. We say (x_{n}) is Cauchy if for each \varepsilon >0 there is an N\in \mathbb {N} such that for all m,n\geq N we have d(x_{n},x_{m})<\varepsilon
Let (X,d) be a Metric Space. Let (x_{n}) be a Convergent sequence in a metric space. Then x_{n} is a Cauchy sequence.

If (x_{n})\to x converges in X, then for each \varepsilon >0 there is an N\in \mathbb {N} such that for all n\geq N, d(x,x_{n})<\frac {\varepsilon }{2}. Then by the triangle inequality, for all m,n\geq N, d(x_{n},x_{m})\leq d(x_{n},x)+d(x,x_{m})<\varepsilon .
Let (X,d) be a Metric Space. We say (X,d) is Complete if every Cauchy sequence converges.
\mathbb {R}^{n} equipped with the Euclidean norm is complete.

fr:title.text: Metric subspace is complete iff it is a closed subset of parent

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Metric subspace is complete iff it is a closed subset of parent

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (X,d) be a Product of nth roots. Let E\subseteq X. Then (E,d) is complete if and only if E is a Closed Subset of X.

(\Longrightarrow ) Assume (E,d) is complete. Then by Subset is closed iff all convergent sequences on the subset have limits there, we will show the limit of a convergent sequence in E is contained in E. Let (x_{n}) be a sequence in E that converges to x\in X. But since E is complete and Convergent sequences are Cauchy, this implies x\in E as desired.

(\Longleftarrow ) Assume E is a closed subset of X. Let (x_{n}) be a Cauchy sequence in E. Then (x_{n}) is a Cauchy sequence in X and X is complete, so (x_{n}) converges to a point x\in X. But by Subset is closed iff all convergent sequences on the subset have limits there, since E is closed in X, the limit of a convergent sequence in E must belong to E. Hence x\in E and E is a complete metric space.
Let (X,d) be a Metric Space. Let E\subseteq X. We define the Diameter of E to be the real number \mathop {\textrm {diam}}\nolimits (E):=\sup \{d(x,y)\mid x,y\in E\}.

Let (X,d) be a Metric Space. Let (E_{n}) be a descending sequence of nonempty subsets of X, i.e., for all m\geq n we have E_{m}\subseteq E_{n}. Then (E_{n}) is called a Contracting Sequence if \lim _{n\to \infty }\mathop {\textrm {diam}}\nolimits (E_{n})=0

Let (X,d) be a Metric Space. Then X is complete if and only if whenever (E_{n}) is a Contracting sequence of nonempty Closed Subsets of X, there is a point x\in X such that \bigcap ^{\infty }_{n=1}E_{n}=\{x\}.

(\Longleftarrow ) Assume that for any contracting sequence (E_{n}) of nonempty closed subsets of X, there is a point x\in X such that \bigcap ^{\infty }_{n=1}E_{n}=\{x\}. Let (x_{n}) be a Cauchy sequence in X. For each index n, define E_{n} to be the closure of the nonempty set \{x_{k}\mid k\geq n\}. Then (E_{n}) is a descending sequence of nonempty closed sets. Since (x_{n}) is Cauchy, the sequence (E_{n}) is contracting. So by assumption there is a point x\in X such that \bigcap ^{\infty }_{n=1}E_{n}=\{x\}. For each n, x is a limit point of \{x_{k}\mid k\geq n\}. Hence we may inductively select a strictly increasing set of integers \{n_{k}\} such that for each index k, d(x,x_{n_{k}})<1/ k. The subsequence (x_{n_{k}}) converges to x. Since (x_{n}) is Cauchy, the whole sequence (x_{n}) converges to x. Therefore X is complete.

Let (X,d) and (Y,\rho ) be Metric Spaces. A function f\colon X\to Y is said to be Continuous at a point x\in X if for each \varepsilon >0 there is a \delta >0 such that for any x\in X, d(x,a)<\delta \quad \hbox {implies}\quad \rho (f(x),f(a))<\varepsilon , or equivalently f(B_{\delta }(x))\subseteq B_{\varepsilon }(f(x)).
Further, we say f is Continuous if it is continuous at every point in X.

fr:title.text: A function is continuous iff it maps convergent sequences to convergent sequences

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A function is continuous iff it maps convergent sequences to convergent sequences

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (X,d) and (Y,\rho ) be Metric Spaces. Let f\colon X\to Y be a function. Then f is continuous at x if and only if for every sequence (x_{n}) in X, if (x_{n})\to x then f(x_{n})\to f(x) in Y.

(\Longrightarrow ) Assume f is continuous at x. Let (x_{n}) be a sequence in X that converges to x. Let \varepsilon >0, we can choose a \delta >0 such that if d(x,a)<\delta then \rho (f(x),f(a))<\varepsilon . Since (x_{n})\to x converges, there is an index N such that for all n\geq N we have d(x,x_{n})<\delta . Then \rho (f(x),f(x_{n}))<\varepsilon for all n\geq N. Hence f(x_{n})\to f(x).

(\Longleftarrow ) Assume for any sequence (x_{n}) in X, if x_{n}\to x, then f(x_{n})\to f(x) in Y. Assume for contradiction that f is not continuous at x. That is, there is some \varepsilon _{0}>0 such that for every \delta >0, there exists an a\in B_{\delta }(x) such that \rho (f(x),f(a))\geq \varepsilon _{0}. In particular, for each n, there exists a point x_{n}\in B_{1/n}(x) such that \rho (f(x),f(x_{n}))\geq \varepsilon _{0}. This defines a sequence (x_{n}) in X that converges to x but whose image sequence (f(x_{n})) does not covnerge to f(x). This contradicts our assumption, hence the result.

fr:title.text: A function is continuous iff the preimage of open sets are open

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A function is continuous iff the preimage of open sets are open

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (X,d) and (Y,\rho ) be Metric Spaces. Let f\colon X\to Y be a function. Then f is continuous if and only if for each open subset O of Y, the preimage f^{-1}(O) is an open subset of X.

(\Longrightarrow ) Assume f is continuous. Let O be a continuous subset of Y. Let x be a point in the preimage f^{-1}(O). We must show that an open ball centered at x is contained in f^{-1}(O). Since f(x) is a point in O, which is open in Y, there is some r>0 such that B_{r}(f(x))\subseteq O. Since f is continuous at x, we can find a \delta >0 such that f(B_{\delta }(x))\subseteq B_{r}(f(x))\subseteq O. Then B_{\delta }(x)\subseteq f^{-1}(O) and therefore f^{-1}(O) is open in X.

(\Longleftarrow ) Assume the preimage under f of each open set of Y is open in X. Let x\in X. Let \varepsilon >0. The open ball B_{\varepsilon }(f(x)) is an open subset of Y. Then f^{-1}(B_{\varepsilon }(f(x))) is open in X. Note that x\in f^{-1}(B_{\varepsilon }(f(x))), so we can choose a \delta >0 such that B_{\delta }(x)\subseteq f^{-1}(B_{\varepsilon }(f(x))). That is, f(B_{\delta }(x))\subseteq B_{\varepsilon }(f(x)).

fr:title.text: A function is continuous iff preimage of closed sets are closed

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A function is continuous iff preimage of closed sets are closed

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (X,d) and (Y,\rho ) be Metric Spaces. Let f\colon X\to Y be a function. Then f is continuous if and only if for each closed subset F of Y, the preimage f^{-1}(F) is a closed subset of X.

Let (X,d) and (Y,\rho ) be Metric Spaces. Let f\colon X\to Y be a function. We say f is Uniformly Continuous if for each \varepsilon >0 there is a \delta >0 such that for all u,v\in X, d(u,v)<\delta \quad \hbox {implies}\quad \rho (f(u),f(v))<\varepsilon .
Let (X,d) and (Y,\rho ) be Metric Spaces. We call a function f\colon X\to Y Lipschitz if there is a c\geq 0 such that for all u,v\in X, \rho (f(u),f(v))\leq c\cdot d(u,v).
We also say f is c-Lipschitz if we want to specify the constant in the inequality. (This constant is also sometimes called the Lipschitz Constant.)
Let (X,d) and (Y,\rho ) be Metric Spaces. Let f\colon X\to Y be a Lipschitz function. Then f is uniformly continuous.
For each \varepsilon >0, let \delta =\varepsilon / c, then the result follows immediately.

fr:title.text: Cover of a subset of a metric space

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Cover of a subset of a metric space

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (X,d) be a Metric Space. Let E\subseteq X. A collection of sets \{U_{\alpha }\}_{\alpha \in A} is a Cover of E if E\subseteq \bigcup _{\alpha \in A}U_{\alpha }.
A Subcover of E is a subset of \{U_{\alpha }\} which is also a cover of E.
We call a cover \{U_{\alpha }\} an Open Cover of E if each U_{\alpha } is an open subset of X.

fr:title.text: Compact subset of a metric space

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Compact subset of a metric space

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (X,d) be a Metric Space. Let K\subseteq X. We call K Compact if every open cover has a finite subcover.
Let (X,d) be a Metric Space. Let E\subseteq X be a subset of X. We say E is Bounded if there is a point x\in X and radius r>0 such that E\subseteq B_{r}(x).

fr:title.text: Compact subsets of metric spaces are closed and bounded

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Compact subsets of metric spaces are closed and bounded

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (X,d) be a Metric Space. Let K\subseteq X be a compact subset of X. Then K is closed and bounded.

Claim 1: K is closed. Let x\in X\setminus K. Then for each z\in K, let r_{z}>0 and s_{z}>0 be such that B_{r_{z}}(z)\cap B_{s_{z}}(x)=\emptyset . We can do this for every z\in K. Then \{B_{r_{z}}(z)\} forms an open cover of K. Since K is compact, it has a finite subcover: B_{r_{1}}(z_{1}), …, B_{r_{k}}(z_{k}) which covers K. Let s=\min (s_{z_{j}}\mid j=1,…,k)\} Then B_{s}(x)\cap B_{z_{j}}(z_{j})=\emptyset for each j=1,…,k. Then B_{s}(x)\cap (B_{r_{1}}(z_{1})\cup …\cup B_{r_{k}}(z_{k}))=\emptyset , so we must have B_{s}(x)\subseteq X\setminus K. Then X\setminus K is open iff K is closed (by A set is open iff its complement is closed).

Claim 2: K is bounded. For any x_{0}\in K, pick \{B_{n}(x_{0})\mid n\in \mathbb {N}\} as an open cover of K. Then there exists a finite subcover. Since B_{m}(x_{0})\subseteq B_{n}(x_{0}) for any m\leq n, this means there exists an N\in \mathbb {N} such that K\subseteq B_{N}(x_{0}). This implies K is bounded.

fr:title.text: Closed subsets of a compact set are compact

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Closed subsets of a compact set are compact

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (X,d) be a Metric Space. Let K\subseteq X be a compact subset of X. Let F\subseteq K be a closed subset. Then F is compact.

Let \{U_{\alpha }\} be an open cover of F. Since F is closed, K\setminus F is open, so \{K\setminus F\}\cup \{U_{\alpha }\} is an open cover of K. Then there exists a finite subcover of K, i.e., there are finitely many U_{\alpha _{1}}, …, U_{\alpha _{n}} such that U_{\alpha _{1}}\cup …\cup U_{\alpha _{n}}=F.

fr:title.text: Continuous image of a compact subset is compact

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Continuous image of a compact subset is compact

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (X,d) and (Y,\rho ) be Metric Spaces. Let K\subseteq X be a compact subset of X. Let f\colon X\to Y be continuous. Then f(K) is a compact subset of Y.

Let \{U_{\alpha }\} be an arbitrary open cover of f(K) in Y. For each x\in K, there is an \alpha such that f(x)\in U_{\alpha }. So x\in f^{-1}(U_{\alpha }). This means \{f^{-1}(U_{\alpha })\} is an open cover of K, since the A function is continuous iff the preimage of open sets are open. This means since K is compact there is a finite subcover \{f^{-1}(U_{\alpha _{i}})\mid i=1,…,n\} of K. So K\subseteq \bigcup ^{n}_{i=1}f^{-1}(U_{\alpha _{i}}). Then f(K)\subseteq \bigcup ^{n}_{i=1}f(f^{-1}(U_{\alpha _{i}}))\subseteq \bigcup ^{n}_{i=1}U_{\alpha _{i}}, hence f(K) is compact.
Let (X,d) be a compact Metric Space. Let f\colon X\to \mathbb {R} be a continuous function, then there are points a,b\in X such that for all x\in X we have f(a)\leq f(x)\leq f(b).

We see that f(X) is compact because the Continuous image of a compact subset is compact, and therefore closed and bounded since Compact subsets of metric spaces are closed and bounded. Let \alpha :=\inf f(X) and \beta :=\sup f(X). By Least-Upper-Bound Property of \mathbb {R} and f(X) is closed, we see \alpha ,\beta \in f(X).

fr:title.text: Totally bounded subset of a metric space

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Totally bounded subset of a metric space

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (X,d) be a Metric Space. Let K\subseteq X. We say K is Totally Bounded if for each \varepsilon >0, K can be covered by a finite number of Open Balls of radius \varepsilon .

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: A totally bounded set is bounded.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X be a set. Let (x_{n}) be a Sequence of X. Consider a sequence (n_{k}) of positive integers such that n_{1}<n_{2}<n_{3}<…. Then the sequence (x_{n_{k}}) is called a Subsequence of (x_{n}).
Let (X,d) be a Metric Space. Let (x_{n}) be a Sequence of X. Let (x_{n_{k}}) be a Subsequence of (x_{n}). If (x_{n_{k}}) converges, its limit is called a Subsequential limit of (x_{n}).
Let (X,d) be a Metric Space. A subset K of X is called Sequentially compact if every sequence in K has a Subsequence that converges to a point in K.

fr:title.text: Characterization of compactness for metric spaces

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Characterization of compactness for metric spaces

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (X,d) be a Metric Space. The following are equivalent:

fr:ol.fr:li: X is complete and totally bounded
X is compact
X is Sequentially compact subset

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We will prove (1)\implies (2)\implies (3)\implies (1). We will provide these as separate proofs.

(1)\implies (2) Assume for contradiction that X is not compact. Then consider an open cover \{U_{\alpha }\} of X such that it has no finite subcover. We will repeatedly use the following construction:

(i) Since X is totally bounded, we can consider a finite collection of open balls of radius r<1 / 2 which cover X. Then at least one of these open balls B_{1} that can not be covered by finitely many U_{\alpha }. We call its closure A_{1}=\overline {B_{1}}. Then A_{1} is closed and \mathop {\textrm {diam}}\nolimits (A_{1})\leq 1.

Using totally boundedness again, repeating (i) but with balls of radius r < 1 / 4, we find another open ball B_{2} whose intersection with A_{1} cannot be covered by finitely many U_{\alpha }. We call the closure of this open ball intersected with A_{1}, A_{2} := \overline {A_{1}\cap B_{2}}. We have B_{2}\cap A_{1} cannot be covered by finitely many U_{\alpha }. Then A_{2} is closed and A_{2}\subseteq A_{1} and \mathop {\textrm {diam}}\nolimits (A_{2}) < 1 / 2.

Case 1: Suppose E is a finite set. Then we can use the pidgeonhole principle: there exists an x\in E repeated infinitely many times, and a sequence (n_{k}) where n_{1} < n_{2} < … of positive integers such that the subsequence (x_{n_{k}}) is identically x. Then x_{n}\to x converges.

Case 2: Suppose E is an infinite set. There are infinitely many distinct terms in (x_{n}). We assume for contradiction that no point in X is a Limit Point of E. Then for each z\in X, there is a Neighborhood U_{z}\ni z which intersects E\cap U_{z}=\{z\} at most trivially. Then \{U_{z}\}_{z\in X} is an open cover of X. This contradicts the hypothesis that X is compact. So we reject the assumption that E has no limit point. Let us call that limit point x\in X. Then we can choose the smallest index n_{1} such that x_{n_{1}}\in B_{1}(x). We can choose n_{k} to be the smallest index such that n_{k}>n_{k-1} and x_{n_{k}}\in B_{1 / k}(x). Then we have constructed a subsequence (x_{n_{k}})\to x. This proves the claim.

(3)\implies (1) Assume X is sequentially compact. Assume for contradiction that X is not totally bounded. Then there exists some \varepsilon >0 such that we cannot cover X with finitely many open balls of radius \varepsilon .

We select a point x_{1}\in X. Then X cannot be covered by B_{\varepsilon }(x_{1}). Then consider x_{2}\in X such that d(x_{1},x_{2})\geq 2\varepsilon . Then B_{\varepsilon }(x_{1})\cap B_{\varepsilon }(x_{2})=\emptyset are disjoint, and B_{\varepsilon }(x_{1})\cup B_{\varepsilon }(x_{2}) does not cover X.

Inductively, we select x_{3}\in X such that \mathop {\textrm {diam}}\nolimits (x_{3},x_{i})\geq 2\varepsilon for i=1,2, so we can continue in this manner to get (x_{n}) a sequence with no convergent subsequence (because any two terms are at least \varepsilon apart). This means X is not sequentially compact. This is a contradiction. Hence X is totally bounded.

But we are not finished, we need to prove X is complete. Let (x_{n}) be an arbitrary Cauchy sequence. Then (x_{n}) has a convergent Subsequence (x_{n_{k}})\to x by sequential compactness. Then (x_{n})\to x since it is a Cauchy sequence (and the triangle inequality).

fr:title.text: Subsets of Euclidean space are bounded iff totally bounded

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Subsets of Euclidean space are bounded iff totally bounded

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A subset of Euclidean space E\subseteq \mathbb {R}^{n} is bounded if and only if it is totally bounded.
(\Longleftarrow ) Obvious.

(\Longrightarrow ) For simplicity, suppose n=2 (the argument generalizes to other n). Let \varepsilon >0. Since E is bounded, there is an Open Ball which totally contains E. There is an a>0 sufficiently large such that E\subseteq [-a,a]\times [-a,a]. Then we can take a partition P_{k} of [-a,a] such that each interval in the partition has length less than 1 / k. Then P_{k}\times P_{k} is a partition of [-a,a]\times [-a,a] and each square has diameter bounded by \sqrt {2} / k. We can choose k sufficiently large such that \sqrt {2} / k < \varepsilon . There are finitely many such open squares which cover E. This implies there are finitely many open balls of radius \varepsilon covering E. Hence the result.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Heine-Cantor theorem
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Gunning's An Introduction to Analysis Theorem 3.18
Royden and Fitzpatrick's Real Analysis, Ch. 9 Proposition 23

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (X,d) and (Y,\rho ) be Metric Spaces. Assume that (X,d) is compact. Let f\colon X\to Y be a continuous function. Then f is uniformly continuous.

Assume for contradiction f is not uniformly continuous. Then there exists an \varepsilon >0 such that for every \delta >0 and for every a,b\in X we have d(a,b)<\delta \quad \hbox {and}\quad \rho (f(a),f(b))\geq \varepsilon . Since (X,d) is compact, it is sequentially compact by Characterization of compactness for metric spaces. Then for each n, there exists x_{n}\in X and y_{n}\in X such that d(x_{n},y_{n})<\frac {1}{n}\quad \hbox {and}\quad \rho (f(x_{n}),f(y_{n}))\geq \varepsilon . But by sequential compactness there exists an x\in X and a subsequence (x_{n_{k}}) such that x_{n_{k}}\to x converges. Then using the triangle inequality, we have \begin {align} d(y_{n_{k}},x) & \leq d(y_{n_{k}},x_{n_{k}}) + d(x_{n_{k}},x)\\ &\leq \frac {1}{n_{k}} + d(x_{n_{k}},x), \end {align} which goes to zero for sufficiently large n_{k}. Then (y_{n_{k}})\to x. Then by continuity of f, their images (using the triangle inequality): \rho (f(x_{n_{k}}), f(y_{n_{k}}))\leq \rho (f(x_{n_{k}}), f(x)) + \rho (f(x), f(y_{n_{k}})), which goes to zero by continuity. But this contradicts \rho (f(x_{n_{k}}),f(x))\geq \varepsilon , hence f must be uniformly continuous.
If (X,d) is a Complete Metric Space and \{O_{n}\} is a sequence of open subsets of X each of which is dense, then \bigcap ^{\infty }_{n=1} O_{n} is dense.
Enough general topology to be dangerous.

Let X be a set. A Topology of X is a collection \mathcal {T} of subsets of X such that:
\emptyset \in \mathcal {T} and X\in \mathcal {T}
Closed under finite intersections: If U_{1},…,U_{n}\in \mathcal {T}, then U_{1}\cap …\cap U_{n}\in \mathcal {T}.
Closed under arbitrary unions: If \{U_{\alpha }\}_{\alpha \in A}\subseteq \mathcal {T} is a collection of elements of \mathcal {T}, then their union \bigcup _{\alpha \in A}U_{\alpha }\in \mathcal {T} belongs to \mathcal {T} as well.
A Topological Space is a set X equipped with a Topology \mathcal {T} of X.
The elements of the topology \mathcal {T} are called Open Subsets of X.
Let (X,\mathcal {T}) be a Topological space. Let x\in X be a point. A Neighborhood of x is an open subset U of X which contains x\in U.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Some authors in older topology texts use a slightly different definition of a neighborhood. So just be careful when consulting a text if they use neighborhoods.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (X,d) be a Metric Space. We can define the Metric Topology for X consisting of all open subsets (defined using open balls) as the only open sets in the topology.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: We should look at point-set topology as generalizing everything from our discussion about the Topology of metric spaces to arbitrary sets.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X be a set. We have the Discrete Topology defined by \mathcal {T}=\mathcal {P}(X). That is to say, every subset of X is open.
Let X be any set. We have the Trivial Topology be \mathcal {T}=\{\emptyset ,X\}.

Let (X,\mathcal {T}) be a Topological space, let E\subseteq X be some arbitrary subset. Then the Subspace (E,\mathcal {S}) of X is given by the Inherited Topology \mathcal {S}=\{U\cap E\mid U\in \mathcal {T}\}.

Let (X,\mathcal {T}) be a Topological space. A Base for \mathcal {T} is a collection \mathcal {B} of open sets such that for every U\in \mathcal {T}, there is a collection of elements B_{\alpha }\in \mathcal {B} such that \bigcup _{\alpha }U_{\alpha }=G.

Let X be a set, let \mathcal {B} be an arbitrary family of subsets of X such that \bigcup \mathcal {B}=X (i.e., they cover X). Then we may define the Topology Generated by \mathcal {B} to be the collection \mathcal {T} of subsets of X such that:
A subset U\subseteq X is an element of \mathcal {T} if for each x\in U there exists a B\in \mathcal {B} such that x\in B and B\subseteq U.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This defines a term "topology generated", but it does not necessarily mean that it's actually a Topology for X. We need to prove it in the next theorem.

fr:title.text: Topology generated by a base really is a topology

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Topology generated by a base really is a topology

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
Let X be a set. Let \mathcal {B} be a collection of subsets for X. Let \mathcal {T} be the Topology Generated by a base. Then \mathcal {B} is a base for \mathcal {T} (and \mathcal {T} really is a Topology) if and only if both
\mathcal {B} covers X, i.e., X=\bigcup \mathcal {B}; and also
for all B_{1},B_{2}\in \mathcal {B}, for all x\in X, if x\in B_{1}\cap B_{2}, then there exists a B\in \mathcal {B} such that x\in B\subseteq B_{1}\cap B_{2}.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: A topology may be generated by many distinct bases. So the base is not unique.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Just an outline of the strategy.
(\Longrightarrow ) Assume \mathcal {B} is a base and its generated topology is \mathcal {T}. Then showing the two conditions are satisfied is straightforward "unfolding the definitions".

(\Longleftarrow ) Let \mathcal {B} be a base for some topology satisfying the two conditions. Then we check the topology generated satisfies the axioms for a Topology. The fact \emptyset \in \mathcal {T} and X\in \mathcal {T} and \mathcal {T} is closed under finite intersection are straightforward. The proof that it is closed under arbitrary union requires a bit more work.
Let X be a set. A Subbase \mathcal {S} is a subset family of X (i.e., a set such that for E\in \mathcal {S}, we see E\subseteq X) such that \bigcup \mathcal {S}=X.
Let X be a set, let \mathcal {S} be a Subbase for topology. We define the Topology Generated by Subbase \mathcal {S} to be the collection \mathcal {T} of arbitrary unions of finite subbase elements.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Again, like Topology Generated by a base, this just defines a multi-word term "topology generated by subbase", but we have not shown this is a topology.

fr:title.text: Topology generated by subbase really is a topology

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Topology generated by subbase really is a topology

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let X be a nonempty set. Let \mathcal {S} be a subbase for X. Then the Topology generated by subbase from \mathcal {S} is a Topology.
Let (X,\mathcal {T}) be a Topological space. Let E\subseteq X be a subset of X. We say E is Closed if E^{\complement }=X\setminus E is open.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Usually F is used as the variable for closed sets, because Bourbaki used it (since the French word for "closed" is Fermé).

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (X,\mathcal {T}) be a Topological space. If \mathcal {F} is the collection of closed subsets of X, then the following all hold:

fr:ol.fr:li: X\in \mathcal {F} and \emptyset \in \mathcal {F}
Intersection of arbitrary family of closed sets is closed: \bigcap \{F_{\alpha }\in \mathcal {F}\mid \alpha \in I\}\in \mathcal {F}
Union of finitely-many closed sets is closed: If F_{1},…,F_{n}\in \mathcal {F}, then F_{1}\cup …\cup F_{n}\in \mathcal {F}.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (X,\mathcal {T}) be a Topological space. Let E\subseteq X. We define the Closure of E to be the set \overline {E} equal to the intersection of all closed sets containing E, \overline {E}:=\bigcap \{F\mid F\hbox { is closed}, E\subseteq F\}.
Note that other possible notations for the closure of E includes \mathop {\textrm {Cl}}(E).

fr:title.text: A set is closed iff it is equal to its own closure

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A set is closed iff it is equal to its own closure

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (X,\mathcal {T}) be a Topological space. Let E\subseteq X. Then E is a closed set if and only if E=\overline {E}.
We see that E\subseteq \overline {E}. It suffices to show E is closed iff \overline {E}\subseteq E.
If E is closed, then E is a closed set such that E\subseteq E. Then by definition of the Closure, \overline {E}\subseteq E.
If \overline {E}\subseteq E, then E=\overline {E}. Then by the Properties of closed subsets (specifically (2)), \overline {E} is closed. So E is closed.
Let (X,\mathcal {T}) be a Topological space. Let A\subseteq B\subseteq X. Then \overline {A}\subseteq \overline {B}.

fr:title.text: Closure of a set is a closed set

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Closure of a set is a closed set

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (X,\mathcal {T}) be a Topological space. Let E\subseteq X. Then \overline {E} is a Closed set.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Closure of a set is smallest closed set containing it

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (X,\mathcal {T}) be a Topological space. Let E\subseteq X be a subset of X. Then for any closed set F\subseteq X such that E\subseteq F, we have the closure of E also be a subset \overline {E}\subseteq F.
Let (X,\mathcal {T}) be a Topological space. Let E\subseteq X be a subset of X. We say a point x\in X is a Limit Point of E if every Neighborhood of x contains a distinct y\in E where y\neq x.

fr:title.text: Convergence of sequence in a topological space

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Convergence of sequence in a topological space

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (X,\mathcal {T}) be a Topological space. Let (x_{n}) be a sequence in X. We say (x_{n}) Converges to x\in X if for each Neighborhood U of x, there is an integer N\in \mathbb {N} such that for each n\geq N we have x_{n}\in U.
We call x the Limit of (x_{n}).

Let (X,\mathcal {T_{1}}) and (Y,\mathcal {T}_{2}) be Topological spaces. Let f\colon X\to Y be a function, let x\in X. We say f is Continuous at a point x if for any Neighborhood V of f(x), there is a Neighborhood U of x such that f(U)\subseteq V.
We say f is Continuous if it is continuous at each point of x.

fr:title.text: A function is continuous iff preimage of open subsets are open

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A function is continuous iff preimage of open subsets are open

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (X,\mathcal {T_{1}}) and (Y,\mathcal {T}_{2}) be Topological spaces. Let f\colon X\to Y be a function. Then f is continuous if and only if for each open subset V\subseteq Y we have its preimage f^{-1}(V)\subseteq X is an open subset of X.

fr:title.text: Composition of continuous functions is continuous

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Composition of continuous functions is continuous

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (X,\mathcal {T_{1}}), (Y,\mathcal {T}_{2}), and (Z,\mathcal {T}_{3}) be Topological spaces. Suppose f\colon X\to Y and g\colon Y\to Z are continuous functions. Then g\circ f\colon X\to Z is continuous.
Let (X,\mathcal {T}) be a Topological space. Let U_{1}, U_{2} be open subsets of X. We say U_{1} and U_{2} Separate X if U_{1}\cap U_{2}=\emptyset and U_{1}\cup U_{2}=X.
In this case, we call U_{1} and U_{2} a Separation of X.
Let (X,\mathcal {T}) be a Topological space. We say the space (X,\mathcal {T}) is Connected if it cannot be separated by any pair of open subsets.
Let (X,\mathcal {T}) be a Topological space. Let E\subseteq X be a subset of X. We say the set E is Connected if the subspace given by E is connected.

fr:title.text: Continuous image of a connected subset is connected

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Continuous image of a connected subset is connected

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (X,\mathcal {T_{1}}) and (Y,\mathcal {T}_{2}) be Topological spaces. Let f\colon X\to Y be a Continuous Function. If E\subseteq X is a Connected Subset, then f(E)\subseteq Y is a connected subset.

Assume for contradiction f(E) is not connected. Then let V_{1} and V_{2} be open subsets of f(E) which separate f(E), so V_{1}\cap V_{2}=\emptyset and V_{1}\cup V_{2}=f(E). Then by continuity, f^{-1}(V_{1}) and f^{-1}(V_{2}) are disjoint open subsets of X whose union is E. This means f^{-1}(V_{1}) and f^{-1}(V_{2}) separate E, which contradicts E being connected.

Let (X,\mathcal {T}) be a Topological space. We say X is Hausdorff if for any two distinct points x,y\in X, there are disjoint open sets U,V\subseteq X such that x\in U and y\in V.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (X,d) be a metric space. Then the Metric topology makes X into a Hausdorff space.
To see this, let x,y\in X be arbitrary and distinct. Let r=d(x,y). Then B_{r / 2}(x) and B_{r / 2}(y) are disjoint open subsets containing x and y, respectively. Hence the claim.

fr:title.text: Sequences in Hausdorff space converge to at most one value

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Sequences in Hausdorff space converge to at most one value

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (X,\mathcal {T}) be a Hausdorff space. Let (x_{n}) be a convergent sequence in X. Then there exists a unique x\in X such that x_{n}\to x.

Assume for contradiction that (x_{n}) converges to two distinct points x\in X and y\in X. Then by Hausdorff property, there are disjoint open neighborhoods U_{x}\ni x and U_{y}\ni y. By definition of Convergence of sequence in a topological space, there are two positive integers N_{x}\in \mathbb {N} and N_{y}\in \mathbb {N} such that for all n\geq N_{x}, x_{n}\in U_{x} and for all n\geq N_{y}, x_{n}\in U_{y}. Setting N=\max (N_{x},N_{y}), then for all n\geq N we have x_{n}\in U_{x}\cap U_{y} which is disjoint. Hence (x_{n}) cannot converge to more than one point in a Hausdorff space.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (X,\mathcal {T}) be a Topological space. Let E\subseteq X be a subset of X. A Open Cover of E is a collection \{U_{\alpha }\}_{\alpha \in A} of open subsets of X such that E\subseteq \bigcup _{\alpha \in A}U_{\alpha }.
Let (X,\mathcal {T}) be a Topological space. Let K\subseteq X be a subset of X. We say K is Compact if every Open cover has a finite open subcover.
Let (X,\mathcal {T}) be a Topological space. Let K\subseteq X be a subset of X. Then the following all hold:

If K is Compact subset and F\subseteq K is closed, then F is compact.
The continuous image of a compact set is compact.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (X,\mathcal {T}) be a compact Hausdorff space. Then a continuous real-valued function takes a maximum and minimum value on X.

Let (X,\mathcal {T_{1}}) and (Y,\mathcal {T}_{2}) be Topological spaces. Let f\colon X\to Y be a Continuous Function. We say f is a Homeomorphism if it is a Bijective function and its Inverse function f^{-1}\colon Y\to X is also continuous.
Let (X,\mathcal {T_{1}}) and (Y,\mathcal {T}_{2}) be Topological spaces. We say (X,\mathcal {T_{1}}) and (Y,\mathcal {T}_{2}) are Homeomorphic if there exists a Homeomorphism between them.
